Computational complexity theory.
Computational problems are classified based on their inherent difficulty.
Computational problem.

Stomatal guard cells contain around 8-15 chloroplasts per cell.
Half a million chloroplasts are in a square mm of a leaf.
Chloroplasts are mainly found in the mesophyll layers and guard cells of stomata in a leaf. They can also be found in bundle sheath cells, especially in C4 plants.
Chloroplasts spread out flat in low-light conditions to maximize surface area for light absorption.
Chloroplasts arrange in vertical columns or turn sideways under intense light to reduce exposure and protect themselves from photooxidative damage.
Turning sideways protects chloroplasts from photooxidative damage.

Land plants have many small chloroplasts instead of a few big ones because this allows them to distribute the chloroplasts to best suit the available light and protect them from photooxidative damage.
Mitochondria have been observed to follow moving chloroplasts.
Plants have two main immune responses.
The hypersensitive response is a plant immune response in which infected cells seal themselves off and undergo programmed cell death.

Systemic acquired resistance is a response in which infected cells release signals warning the rest of the plant of a pathogen's presence, triggering defense-molecule production in the rest of the plant.

Chloroplasts trigger the plant's immune system by purposely damaging their photosynthetic system, producing reactive oxygen species that stimulate both the hypersensitive response and systemic acquired resistance.
Damaging photosynthesis systems creates reactive oxygen species, which stimulate both the hypersensitive response and systemic acquired resistance in plants.
Salicylic acid, jasmonic acid, nitric oxide, and reactive oxygen species act as defense signals.
Chloroplasts produce defense signals after detecting stress in a cell, which might be due to a pathogen.
Reactive oxygen species signals from chloroplasts are passed on to an unknown second messenger molecule within the chloroplast.
Retrograde signaling is a process where signals from the chloroplast regulate gene expression in the nucleus.
The most important role of chloroplasts is to facilitate photosynthesis, the process by which light is transformed into chemical energy to produce food in the form of sugars.
The process of changing light into chemical energy is called photosynthesis.
Chemical energy is used to produce food in the form of sugars in plants.
The molecular inputs for photosynthesis are water (H2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2).
The molecular outputs for photosynthesis are sugar and oxygen.
Chloroplasts use the potential energy stored in an H+ gradient to generate ATP energy, like mitochondria.
Chloroplasts pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space.
The hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space can be up to a thousand times more concentrated than in the stroma.
ATP synthase changes adenosine diphosphate (ADP) into adenosine triphosphate (ATP).
ATP stands for adenosine triphosphate.
NADP+ usually takes reenergized electrons.
Electrons are recycled in cyclic photophosphorylation.
Cyclic photophosphorylation is common in C4 plants.
C4 plants need more ATP than NADPH.
The Calvin cycle.
The result of the Calvin cycle is the production of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (G3P) sugar molecules.
Unstable 6-carbon molecules immediately break down into three-carbon molecules called 3-phosphoglyceric acid, or 3-PGA.
One out of every six G3P molecules leaves the cycle.
Glucose monomers in the chloroplast can be linked together to make starch.
Starch grains may become overly large under conditions such as high atmospheric CO2 concentrations or waterlogged roots.
Starch grains become overly large and distort the grana and thylakoids in the chloroplast under conditions such as high atmospheric CO2 concentrations.
Waterlogged roots can cause starch buildup in chloroplasts.
Starch grains in chloroplasts might simply be a side effect of another photosynthesis-depressing factor.
Rubisco can add oxygen instead of carbon dioxide to RuBP by mistake.
Photorespiration can occur when the oxygen concentration is too high.

Using O2 instead of CO2 in photosynthesis is less efficient because it leads to photorespiration, which consumes ATP and oxygen, releases CO2, and produces no sugar, wasting up to half the carbon fixed by the Calvin cycle.
Up to half the carbon fixed by the Calvin cycle can be wasted by using O2 instead of CO2.

The most basic method to test the primality of an integer n is trial division, which involves dividing n by each integer m greater than 1 and less than or equal to the square root of n. If none of these divisions result in an integer, then n is prime.

Knowing a complete list of primes up to the square root of n makes the method of trial division more efficient as it only requires checking for divisions with those primes, rather than all integers between 2 and the square root of n.
greater than 1 and less than or equal to the square root of n.
